notes:
1. Purpose and Terminology

Traffic signals are control devices used to assign the right-of-way to conflicting traffic movements at an intersection. The design and timing of signals is a key part of traffic engineering.

  • Cycle Length (C): The total time required for one complete sequence of all signal indications.
  • Phase: A part of the cycle allocated to any combination of traffic movements receiving the right-of-way simultaneously.
  • Interval: A period of time during which all signal indications are fixed (unchanged). The main intervals are Green, Yellow, and All-Red.

2. Change and Clearance Intervals

The transition from green to red is a critical safety period. It consists of the yellow change interval and may include an all-red clearance interval.

  • Yellow Change Interval ($t_y$): Warns drivers that the green is ending and the red is about to begin. It should be long enough for a driver to either come to a safe stop before the intersection or to proceed through the intersection before the red light appears.
    • $$ t_y = t_p + \frac{v}{2a} $$

    where $t_p$ is the driver perception-reaction time (typically 1.0 s), $v$ is the approach speed, and $a$ is the comfortable deceleration rate.

  • All-Red Clearance Interval ($t_{ar}$): An optional interval that follows the yellow, during which all approaches have a red light. It provides time for a vehicle that entered the intersection at the end of the yellow to clear the intersection before the conflicting traffic is released.
    • $$ t_{ar} = \frac{W+L}{v} $$

    where $W$ is the width of the intersection, $L$ is the length of the vehicle, and $v$ is the approach speed.

3. Dilemma Zone

The dilemma zone is an area on the approach to a signalized intersection where a driver, upon the onset of the yellow light, can neither come to a safe stop before the intersection nor clear the intersection before the red light. The proper calculation of the yellow interval is intended to eliminate this dilemma zone.

solvedExamples.question: What is the primary purpose of the yellow change interval at a traffic signal?

options.text: To allow more cars to get through the intersection.
To warn drivers of an impending change in the right-of-way.
To provide time for pedestrians to cross.

solvedExamples.explanation: The yellow interval serves as a warning that the green light is ending and a red light will soon be displayed. It gives drivers time to decide whether to stop safely or to proceed through the intersection if they are too close to stop.

solvedExamples.question: A vehicle is approaching an intersection at 45 ft/s. The intersection is 60 ft wide and the vehicle length is 20 ft. What is the required all-red clearance interval for this vehicle to clear the intersection?
solvedExamples.explanation: The all-red interval provides time for the vehicle to travel a distance equal to the width of the intersection plus its own length. $t_{ar} = (W+L)/v = (60 \text{ ft} + 20 \text{ ft}) / 45 \text{ ft/s} = 80 / 45 \approx 1.78$ seconds.
